Comment: OMG, listening to yourselves guys, the whole discussion didn‚Äôt mention one most important thing about the condition precedent for a parliamentary democracy like other Commonwealth countries, Malaysia is a parliamentary democracy too! Malaysia‚Äôs Federal Constitution - Article 43(2) provides that the Yang di-Pertuan Agong shall appoint a PM ‚Äúwho in his judgment is likely to command the confidence of the majority of the members of the Dewan the people‚Äù. PH has the most seats at GE15 though not reaching 112, PH has the most electorate mandate to form the next government & Anwar Ibrahim be appointed the PM, merely based on ‚Äúfirst past the post‚Äù principle which is the heart of parliamentary democracy. It‚Äôs rubbish to say or as the panels suggested PN, is more popular to form a government, the people(voters) had spoken on 19.11.2022. The voters had given the mandate to PH to form the government whether you like it or NOT, appointing any other candidate other than Anwar Ibrahim would be ANTI-DEMOCRATIC, and would go against of the millions of voters who gave PH‚Äôs coalition 82 parliamentary seats!!! Sorry, it is disappointing that the panels aren‚Äôt qualified to talk about this topic, their opinions should at least be guided by  the Federal Constitution of Malaysia, not conjectures!

Name: @hizzaddinno394
Comment: The world needs to keep an eye on Najib - right now he's engaged in an image rebranding campaign aimed at improving his battered public image. The campaign is elegant, simple and effective at reacquiring Barisan National party members, Malay and youth support. He uses humour to affect a nascent but growing disregard of his (accused) crimes. The campaign's motto is "Malu apa, bossku?" which can be translated as "What have you got to be ashamed of, ma' boss?". Basically, he's trying to downplay the accusations of high level corruption and also rebrand his image into an image of an average joe's hero. He even goes so far as to "forgive" the people of Malaysia for his downfall. And it is working - the Malay mindset is quick to forget and forgive (in that specific order), especially when dealing with powerful, rich or influential individuals, even when they themselves were the ones previously exploited by the individual. Some nice chin-wagging and all's forgiven... Allah save us. It was international shame that brought him down but like a bacteria, he's trying to gain resistance to the antibiotic of corruption.

Name: @RalphieM92
Comment: As a Malaysian who followed politics since 11years old, I had the opportunity to finally vote and campaign with my state candidates. I also had the chance to be a station master ( voting station supervisor ) to assure that no gerrymandering happens under my watch during the voting day. Throughout the years, I had seen so much dissatisfaction among the people especially among the chinese and indians, not to be a racist but the truth as i have many friends of different races, as the recent years passed, even the malays started to feel they were being played a fool by the government they once and always supported. Now for us, those who always wanted a change can finally breathe a huge sigh of relief because we had turn a dream into reality. Its true it is too early to say Malaysia is saved, but it is never too late for a fresh start. But one thing for sure, PH has done more in a month than BN in the last few years. But no matter who voted for who, we are still a proud nation, and I am glad that no civil war or violence erupted from this election and change of government. They arent anymore Malays, Indians or Chinese, we are all Malaysians, rebuilding our nation, freeing it from corruption.

Name: @hareshgill
Comment: A good narration of the chronology of events that have happened thus far. Happy to hear progressive comments from the newcomers interviewed in this piece from a number of individuals who offer their perspectives on the current political situation in Malaysia, namely Zaim Mokhzani, Isham Jalil, Dr, Noorshahril Saat, and Dr. Ahmed Razman.¬†..Special thanks to Mohd. Nazrul Hakim who advocates for a clean and fair Govt, Mr. Voon Zhen Yi who sees potential in a fair democratic Govt, Faye Lim who speaks passionately and feels our pain as the people, En. Zool Amali saw the light for future Malaysians (Respect Tuan), Nornajwa Hidayah the young critical thinker that simply makes sense (wish for more young Malaysians like her).¬†..We also hear from Dr. Chandra Muzaffar, who provides historical context for the current political situation in Malaysia. Overall, this piece offers a diverse range of perspectives on the current state of politics in Malaysia and encourages viewers to think critically about the future of Malaysia...In conclusion, let us all give this Unity government a fair full term to make Malaysia great again. Hopefully, this inclusive piece will get to the mainstream media so that everyone can appreciate and remember the sentiments expressed by those interviewed. Bottom line, let's give this Unity govt a fair full term to make Malaysia, the Asian Tiger, great again!

Name: @jp2916
Comment: As a young Malaysian, I hold a deep love and pride for my country and its rich cultural heritage. Despite this, I have been deeply disappointed by the actions and decisions of my government, who are supposed to serve and protect the interests of the country and its citizens. The constant political drama and instability have left me feeling numb and disillusioned. Working overseas has provided me with the necessary perspective to focus on more important aspects of my life, rather than becoming consumed by the disappointing state of my country's politics. I have come to realize that my foreign colleagues possess a better understanding of my country's situation than I do, and while this may be embarrassing, I have simply lost interest and feel disenchanted.

Name: ‚Ü≥ @jp2916
Comment:
An additional viewpoint:..I deeply respect the significance of religious faith. However, it becomes problematic when it is utilized as a political slogan and one particular race is targeted, such as the Malays in Malaysia. This raises important questions about equality and fairness, like why one culture is given special treatment over others, what happens to the voices and needs of other races and cultures, and why is favoritism so openly practiced causing feelings of discrimination among other races.
.
.If Malaysia truly wants to embrace its claimed multiracial and multicultural identity, then it shouldn't be promoting the interests of just one race or using religion as a political tool. This kind of racial favoritism, even if promised by politicians, only serves to deepen division and segregation.
.
.If, however, the authorities acknowledge that Malaysia is not truly a multiracial and multicultural country, and instead favors one specific race, then I could understand the favoritism. But as it stands, Malaysia claims to be a diverse and inclusive the people, and thus, all races should be treated equally and their cultures celebrated to make Malaysia a rich and thriving country, without one race being elevated above others. I acknowledge that this viewpoint may be a sensitive topic for some, and I apologize for that.

Comment: Not a lot of insight about the unity government as a result of GE15 apart from Dr. Chandra's viewpoint that PAS strength is only temporary. I also don't understand why CNA gave Mahatir the platform to say that he thinks he still has a good number of supporters when his constituents and every seat contested by his party voted them out. The guy did more harm than good for Malaysia and is responsible for the narrative of hate towards the Chinese by saying that Malays can't do business, the reduction of reserves for pegging the RM against the dollar, introducing a protectionist economy that increased the cost of living and big purchases, such as cars.¬†..Also, there were no analysis on how Anwar can unite a divided Malaysia. What a lost opportunity. We can see that Malays want an islam-centric and a corrupt-free government. So what can Anwar do to appease and attract these voters and reach out to them and listen to them? Zahid and DAP are baggages, so there must be steps to cut off ties that link corruption to the Unity government. While Anwar constantly blasts about a corrupt-free government, he needs to better show results of good governance. Anwar also needs to reach out to the Malay community who didn't vote for him and ensure that DAP can never hold important ministry positions that matter to the safety and security of the country and Islam. The analyst who said that the trend towards more conservatism in the West is a trend but is partly due to the aging population of those countries who will tend to vote for issues that matter to them. For Malaysia, the movement towards an Islam-centric ideology is due to the divide within public and private/semi-private education and policies that only served urban and politically-connected Malays. The rural Malays are still under-served so they will vote for Islam-centric parties because they are marginalized and ignored and their local mosques are their refuge. We saw how conservative forms of Islam have taken root in other countries. One way of reversing this trend is to educate and give Malay women careers and wealth so they can lose their dependency towards men.

Name: @anwarag263
Comment: Many people don't know that there are actually a lot of efforts from the government for the enjoyment of all of us, not necessarily other countries can provide facilities for THEIR PEOPLE, but our government provides us with cheap hospitals, cheap primary and high schools, there is food assistance, scholarship assistance, IPTS/IPTS and many others. There are no other aspects yet. About 1MDB, the PM is indeed deceived but we blame him Many people don‚Äôt know that the government has made a lot of efforts for the benefit of all of us. Not every country can provide facilities for its people, but our government provides us with affordable hospitals, primary and secondary schools, food aid, scholarship aid, IPTS/IPTS (higher education), and many other things. This doesn‚Äôt even cover other aspects. About 1MDB, the Prime Minister was indeed deceived, yet we blame him without knowing the whole story. Our Prime Ministers have indeed worked to improve our country's economy and provide many facilities for the younger generation. Our PM is actually the one aiming to end "cronyism, monopoly, and nepotism" later on. People criticize him without understanding. Some have personal grudges because the PM cut ties with them; they were rich while the people were left struggling. Our PM, however, comes from a noble lineage in Pahang, dating back to the feudal era. I understand that voting is our right, but we should make the right choice so that future generations can enjoy what we have today rather than watching our wealth deplete. Name: ‚Ü≥ @anwarag263
Comment: there will be changes in the government; that‚Äôs inevitable. But we should be grateful that, for now, we can live peacefully in our own country. The government has done a lot for us, but we overlook it and focus on minor faults, forgetting all past contributions. Sure, Singapore is prosperous and wealthy, but do Malays there have competitive strength? The economy is mostly controlled by the Chinese there. Do we really want the special privileges of Malays and the Bumiputra of Sabah and Sarawak to be erased? Have you ever worked under a foreign-owned company? How were you treated? Do you want our beloved country to be ruled by non-Malays? Foreigners are already wealthier than Malays; where does that leave us as Malays and the Bumiputra of Sabah and Sarawak? Do we want foreigners getting rich off our homeland? If we want to progress, we should hold our representatives accountable, not the entire government. If we want progress, it‚Äôs simple‚Äîsend our kids to school, get them into university, and find jobs, whether government or private. Malaysia uses the slogan "Look East" (Japan) for a reason. Look at Japan: they‚Äôre developed, but their people work hard. They‚Äôre diligent; what about us Malays? We‚Äôre quick to criticize but slow to be grateful. Other countries envy Malaysia because every state here has development and advancement, even if it‚Äôs slow. We blame the government for our children or nephews and nieces not going to school or loitering. But when there‚Äôs an economic crisis, we put the blame on the government. I‚Äôm not pro-BN, but I‚Äôm grateful. My family may not be wealthy, but thank God all my siblings are educated. I hope Sabah has more job opportunities in the future. Name: ‚Ü≥ @herokiryu2652
Comment: @Eddie Ng....Thats what i am saying, rich people have high return because they have a lot of appreciating assets which increase with inflation, when the invest in stock market, their rate of return is more. Poor people however have more depreciating assets and less savings and less investment, in a capitalist system, inflation is proportional to growth, the higher the growth, the more resources consume, the more consumption ,the increase of demand hence increase price. ..Price can be regulated through free market mechanisms or through government policies. Thus the government to regulate the economy through enacted fiscal or monetary policies requires a lot of tax payer reserves. Thus you pay GST, 6% goes to the implementation of Fiscal or Monetary policies, such as regulating currency, China spends 60 billion on regulating its currency. ..What you are complaining is more of the result of a free market system rather than actual Govt incompetence. The reality is that in a capitalist system, you will always make more and more money because the market mechanism is such that it accelerate the income of those who are already wealthy, while those who are poor will always have to cope with this system. ..Thats why education is important, and to have a stable market, where having a skilled labor force is much more important than having the Govt spoon feed you everyday, the Govt can only regulate market mechanisms, but cannot warrant that you do well with your economic situation. So your expectations are unrealistic unless you believe in Communist ideology and Welfare state in which are failing in US and Europe...So please if you think that the alternative Govt takes over, what are they going to do that is so different?

Name: ‚Ü≥ @whathaff
Comment: It's not 0.1% now is it? Regulating prices through free market should also account exchange rates. Consumer Price Index alone cannot be the driving force of how the inflation has gone through since the implementation of GST. Mamak stalls and those hawkers and sundry shops in villages for example had hiked up their prices upto 20% since 2015, citing GST price issues. Those are places where lower income group patronage. ..Currency regulation needs federal reserves, which is also depleting. Internal economy is driven by jobs creation, and purchasing power is driven by income of the people. If the income increase do not equate the percentage of price of goods hike, you get stale economy...Education - tell me this, have you been to the public schools of late? Have you been to the schools in the rural side of Malaysia? Have you seen the standard of schools there? You are living in an ideal world, where reality of what this country is going through is not sinking in, or you do not see anything outside your tunnel vision. ..GST is unnecessary is there are no wastage in the governing body.  If you have time, please find the latest accounts that was published and you will see the amount of wastage in terms of government spending. Name: @djungelskog3434
Comment: Politics isn't supposed to be some competition, politicians are supposed to run for the betterment of their constituents' livelihoods. It doesn't matter which party becomes the majority or wins as long as the one in charge brings the country into prosperity. Unfortunately it seems that our current politicians only have their own self interests in mind, from doing unnecessary renovations to their offices and buying fancy cars to escort them... And let's be honest, if you want to advertise yourself as a multicultural country, maybe you shouldn't put one race above the rest. Otherwise just drop the act. If this was done in the US it would be called out as supremacist immediately. And there never was a democracy here, they'll always find some way to tip the scales in their favor to get back in power, and if you're caught speaking even the slightest insult about the King you go to jail, so much for freedom of speech as well. Royal pardon is literally the 'get out of jail free card' of Malaysian politics. Where is that royal pardon for those who were wrongfully convicted? Furthermore, if you want everyone to be treated equally, you need to have a secular government and not involve your religious agendas. The problem with politics today is that allegiances are fragile and self interest is placed on a higher pedestal than the common folk. Also, Mahatir really needs to stop pointing fingers. No good politician should shift the blame to others as they know fully well that they're responsible for running the whole show. If there's a falling out, it's most likely because he didn't play his cards right. That's all there is. Someone who blames others for their failures and doesn't do any introspection shouldn't run for Prime Minister either. Anwar shouldn't have the seat handed to him because of a promise either. He needs to show us that he's worth our support. Sometimes it just feels like we're just choosing the least worst option out of all parties at times.

Name: @profearoum
Comment: Najib brought significant reforms in governance in Malaysia where government officials and ministers have KPIs where their performance are graded, taxation improved in the form of GST where it would be impossible for rich people and businesses to avoid paying taxes, social security and infrastructure like BR1M and UTC were introduced so that the poor and middle class were aided financially and their lives made easier in a systematic manner without having the need to rely on any persons thus making cronyism much more difficult to implement where every benefit by the government is directly given to citizens without having to go through any political party or individual. During Najib's premiership of 8 years, hundreds of Malay natives became millionaires because of the non-crony capitalism economic policy that Najib implemented. Everything was steadily getting better and getting good in Malaysia, too good, especially freedom of speech that resulted in a lot of lies, political propaganda conspiracy theories and false promises. After 8 years of prosperity, Malaysians especially the Malays have become gullible, arrogant and ungrateful especially the younger generation, and the intensity due to the freedoms personally guaranteed by Najib himself (in his efforts to make Malaysia a developed country) with regards to freedom of speech was capitalized to its fullest by PH, the then opposition during Najib's tenure as Prime Minister. If anything that was Najib's biggest mistake, even in the west today western intellectuals have been trying to improve on the notion of freedom of speech by saying "freedom of speech does not mean freedom from consequences". The hope now is that Najib will learn from his past mistake by being more stern with regards to false allegations and have a team to take these false allegations to court, which is in line with the aspirations of even PH that is the rule of law. But knowing Najib for the type of leader he is, I seriously doubt that he would do that, then my hope is that Malaysian would be wiser and take the extra necessary steps to do their own research before jumping to conclusions at the slightest glimpse of a hyped up basedless controversy just because it's trending on social media.
